ratings.comment: My only interaction with Prof Nyhart was in office hours, it was an asynchronous class. She is very knowledgeable but does not answer questions very clearly. "Well there is no one right answer" "Shouldn't that be obvious?" "Think about it some more", if you do not have a good TA, good luck.

Professor Nyhart cares about her students and their well-being. The class had a lot of reading, especially as a class that mostly freshman take. Her quizzes were very specific and hard to get a 100% on even if you did all the readings and lectures. The class also included weekly discussion posts and some papers and she offered extra credit.

Took this class during COVID so it was all online. She is a caring professor and is invested in the topics presented. There is a lot of reading with very specific quizzes each week, but the two lowest scores were dropped. There were a few assignments and a 1000 word paper final. Put in the time, use the course materials, and you'll get an A.

The content was interesting, but the mid-weekly quizzes had a couple of difficult questions EVEN IF YOU READ EVERYTHING. Readings were given ahead of time, but who has time on the weekend to start when they still have other homework from the week? It was incredibly rare for me to score 100% on anything, despite all the time and effort I gave.

The scheduling of this class was awful all the work was assigned over the weekend and due midday Wednesday. Quizzes were extremely confusing and overly specific even if you did all the work. It was very hard and is not a good class to take as a freshman. Professor Nyhart seemed very nice and the content was somewhat interesting but DON'T DO IT.
Professor Nyhart's lectures were interesting and well structured. The class was lots of fun, and a great way to get humanities credits while being a STEM major.
Difficult to follow lectures. Take thorough notes, pay attention to minute details. Would not recommend taking this class as a freshman.
I took an honors course with her and it involved a lot of readings and we intensively discussed them in lecture

Professor Nyhart is awesome and really cares about having her students do well. Her assignments are fair and the expectations are clear. Sometimes they're a bit challenging, but she understands that and takes that into consideration when grading. Really enjoyed this class with her!

Engaging and very knowledgeable. Assigns a lot of material, but she's aware when some of it may be difficult and helps students understand it. Can be a tough grader, though not unfairly so. Really pushes students to a higher level. A good class and professor.

Knowledgable professor, definitely knows her stuff and tries her best to explain it to her students in layman's terms. Puts lots of effort into relating to her students, very good class to take at the beginning of college; she really guides you into the "college" frame of mind. She's definitely no pushover but her grading is fair if not generous.
If you want inconsistent grading, take this class. If you also want to waste your tuition, take this class. I finish this class as a less-educated individual, thanks to professor Nyhart.

Take if you're good at writing papers. The grade was based on attendance/discussion (grading was lenient here), and three papers. The way this class/Nyhart worked is that if you were interested in the material, you could learn a lot, but if you weren't, it was very easy to copy her powerpoint lectures down and space out the rest of the time.
(history of science). only three papers. more than one reading per class and they  are long. Don't have to read all of it to get a good grade. Small class so you have to participate in discussion.
She has a tenuous grasp on technology and sometimes gets her facts mixed up.  There is also a disproportional amount of work for the class level, but it's all pretty easy.

Completely mistake for me to take -- as a science major, the only thing I got out of this class was frustration with having to write papers, considering that it did not fulfill history credit. The grading was fair, although there was a lot of reading.
she confuses herself sometimes....

She's very organized and enthusiastic about her topic of study, but it can be rather hard to pay attention in lecture. She doesn't do midterms. So if you show up and write decent essays, you'll do fine.

Lynn's lectures are clear and organized, although a little dry. She is confident about what she has to say, but doesn't engage the class or hold their attention very well. Basically, if you do everything required of you and listen in class, you will do fine. It's just hard to keep your eyes open sometimes.

Nyhart obviously cares about this subject. She is very organized and generally clear. I don't like science, so the class was boring. It wasn't hard though. There are no exams, only midterm and final papers. If you stay on top of the reading, this class will be easy, though kind of boring.

Very helpful if you ask for it.  I found the lectures highly stimulating when I made the effort to pay close attention, though it was hard in the morning.  She's also very friendly and interested in her students.  Her lecture outlines could be more thorough but they're better than most profs'.  The written exams are rather long--7-9+ pages.

The class is pretty easy, and she's very helpful if you are in need of help.  I think she'd be better suited as a high school teacher.  Sometimes lectures were very boring, but for the most part, it's just a standard, passable class.
Issues we covered were often obscure.  Victorian England could have been presented in a more appealing fashion by this professor.
She really takes a lot of interest in her students.  Her lectures are quite well-organized too.
All the information is good, but her lectures tend to be a little bit soporific.  She is by far the better of the two professors teaching the class.
